items.title: Wondering if it would be possible to have linux vst or lv2 version
items.body: Hello, I got rather interested in the project and while I don't really know too much about building vst software from source, I would like to know if linux versions could be possible. Thank you.

items.title: Use DPF?
items.body: The [DISTRHO Plugin Framework](https://github.com/DISTRHO/DPF) can build to to VST2, LV2, LADSPA and DSSI formats, as well as a standalone JACK app. Maybe it could be something to consider if you get time to come back to axiom in the future :)

items.title: Can't reliably get the UI to show up after reloading Reaper project
items.body:
Hi,
I'm using the packed Axiom 0.4.3 win32 build with Reaper v5.80 x64.

When I create a new project I can open and close the Axiom UI without issue. I then save the project, close Reaper, and load the project again. There now seems to be no way to bring up the Axiom UI.

Let me know how I can help you improve this bug report, and thanks for this great project! :)

items.title: Investigate and guard against min/max supported converter values

labels.name: backend
labels.description: Issues related to audio backends

items.body: It's currently possible to get NaN values just by feeding out-of-range values into converters or DSP functions. We should look at what the ranges for these actually are, and add safeguards to them to prevent this.

items.body: Attempting to open an Axiom project that has been previously saved and closed within a FL Studio file (not saved externally) and then editing or playing a note results in Axiom crashing.

items.title: SV Filter NaN Bug

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

items.body: Increasing the 'Q' value on the SV filter beyond ~2 with both non-zero frequency and input values produces NaN, which requires deleting to fix.

items.title: Custom Startup
items.body: Instead of just starting with Keyboard 1 and Speakers 1, the default startup can be changed to a chosen axiom file.

items.title: Rename `next` function to `last`

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

items.body: The current name is incorrect, since it returns the _previous_ value that was passed in, not the next one.

items.title: Maxim code upgrade infrastructure

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

items.body:
Since it is useful to be able to modify Maxim function names and signatures, it should actually be possible to setup some sort of upgrade system for code that automatically applies changes to get the code working as expected.

E.g. in the recent case of the `adsr` function's return type being changed from `num` to `(num, num)`, we could automatically modify code that uses it:

```
out:num = adsr(trig:num, a:num, d:num, s:num, r:num)
# becomes
(out:num, _) = adsr(trig:num, a:num, d:num, s:num, r:num)
```

And similar modifications could be made to function parameters (modifying them to pass in some default value).

Of course, this is would be a rather complicated undertaking, and since we're still in version 0.x I'm not too worried about it yet.

items.title: Add separate "pre-generate" callback to allow preparations before a batch of generate calls

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

milestone.description: Main Features include the exporter, XY control, scissors tool, oscilloscope visual, dB meter visual, an in-built keyboard and squashed bugs.

items.body: This should allow us to optimize some functions like `delay` and the various biquad filters where changing a parameter is expensive, by only performing recalculations once before a batch.

items.title: Move language documentation to be in the repo
items.body: The problem with having the documentation in a separate wiki is it's not versioned along with the actual software. This means when working on a new version, we can't progressively update the documentation and instead have to do it all at the end, to ensure it's accurate and current.

items.title: Add "active" output to ADSR function
items.body: This makes it easier to use in voices.

items.title: Better 'builtin module' upgrade system

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

items.body:
Currently modules changed in the builtin library often aren't copied to the global library properly, because the import silently fails due to a conflict.

We could just overwrite modules in the global library with those in the builtin library on upgrade, but this means if the user modifies one of the modules it will be lost.

Here's a proposal for a new design:

 - We add some tag to modules to signify if they're builtin or not.
 - Builtin modules are only stored in the builtin library file, and never saved in the global library file.
 - Builtin modules are read-only, and attempting to modify one prompts a dialog asking the user if they would like to copy the module to their own library.

This concept could be generalized to 'remote modules', opening the possibility of module libraries being sourced from places other than the filesystem (e.g. a website).

items.title: Instrument exporter, closes #87

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: Issues related to the exporter and exporter-generated code

items.body:
This PR adds the instrument exporter. This is responsible for taking a project and building an object file from it, which provides a low-level C interface.

The implementation of this involves two parts: the backend (which takes in a transaction and configuration, and outputs the files), and the frontend (which allows the user to adjust the configuration).

As specified in #87, the exporter also enables several MIR passes with the goals of reducing redundant and unnecessary code.

items.title: Search Bar Clear

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

items.body: A cross button to the left of the node search bar would make for easy 'search clearing'. An alternative would be to always highlight the text in the search bar whenever it's selected but I personally think a cross would be better.

items.title: Chalk Mode

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

items.body:
A useful way of group related nodes together (without group node) would be with a 'chalk-like' mode that allows you to draw a white dashed line in the editor.
For example, if there's compressor related nodes (like compress -> filter -> gain), a dashed outline could be drawn around these nodes to make it clearer what their purpose in the synth is. 
(This is also simply a line, so nothing is forced in or out of it, you could have a node on top of the line)

items.title: Fix incorrect DPI scaling of surfaces

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include the exporter, XY control, scissors tool, oscilloscope visual, dB meter visual, an in-built keyboard and squashed bugs.

items.body:
Currently the scaling of surface content on monitors with non-1 DPI scaling is completely out of whack. Text is the correct size, but everything else is unscaled so the text appears huge (and often clipped).

This should be fixable by multiplying/dividing by `Application::desktop()->devicePixelRatio()` wherever necessary.

items.title: SSE & other performance improvements

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

items.body:
This PR vastly improves performance of audio generation, by doing the following things:

 - Code generation now uses SSE which allows denormals to be disabled and the left and right channels to be calculated at the same time. ~Currently LLVM is set to emit AVX2 code (and hence also AVX and SSE4.2) - this might be a bit too high since AVX2 is relatively new?~ We now detect at runtime if we can enable SSE4.2, AVX, or AVX2. Some math intrinsics have a hard dependency on SSE4.1 though, so we can't go lower than that.
 - As part of the change to SSE, all audio code now uses doubles. This also involves a few changes to the project schema (since control values now need to be stored as doubles).
 - `num` values are now passed by-value into every function, which reduces the amount of loads/stores required and means for most cases the numbers can be stored entirely in registers.
 - All relevant intrinsic math functions have been rewritten in vectorized code, meaning we no longer rely on libm, and math operations are insanely fast.
 - While rewriting the math intrinsics I added a few that were missing, so there are a couple of new functions exposed on Maxim too.

I haven't yet tested this on macOS ~or 64-bit Windows~ (have tested on 64-bit Windows and it works fine, pretty sure there shouldn't be any problems with macOS), so there are probably still a few broken things on both. Thanks to the CI I know it builds on macOS at least...

items.title: Euler Function exp()

labels.name: library
labels.description: Issues related to the builtin module library

items.body: The current method for using euler's number in Maxim is E, but a function exp() would also be intuitive to add.

items.title: Static build on Mac building but not running
items.body:
After some wrangling Axiom is building statically on my Mac but when it runs I get:
```
"/Users/user/Bounce/groove-axiom/cmake-build-static-debug/editor/backend/standalone/Axiom Standalone.app/Contents/MacOS/Axiom Standalone"
2018-11-14 12:37:39.243647+0000 Axiom Standalone[51624:456889] ASSERT failure in QVariant: "Trying to construct an unknown type", file kernel/qvariant.cpp, line 1136
Signal: SIGABRT (signal SIGABRT)
```
Which occurs when QVariant::create is called with type QVariant::Brush (66).
In order to get static linking working I referred to this:
http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/osx-deployment.html
But when not using QMake it seems that many libraries and macOS frameworks must be linked in CMake.
Any ideas about what might be causing the current runtime error would be useful. A possible clue is that HandlersManager::registerHandler in qvariant.cpp is never called, so perhaps the Brush type is never being registered for some reason?

items.title: Conditional statement
items.body:
So this isn't actually a pull request yet, it's a rough sketch of what a conditional statement might look like (I thought Maxim could use one?). However, this is my first time writing Rust and I've only dabbled lightly in compilers before.. so apologies for the sharp edges and lack of it compiling atm. 

I thought I'd ask your opinions @cpdt before I go too much further/ make any structural changes to what already exists. Any pointers are useful, I suspect some change might be necessary to codegen but I don't want to be too brutal - I imagine you probably have some reasons for the current architecture!

Also, how are you debugging the parser at the moment? I thought some tests (like https://github.com/TheDan64/inkwell/tree/master/tests/all) might be useful but haven't set any up yet.

**Parsing**
- Maxim code is matched by regexes in parser/token_stream.rs. Added (broken I suspect) matchers for if, then and else.
- Added tokens If, Then, Else to parser/token.rs
- Added parse_conditional_expr to parser/mod.rs (loosely from https://github.com/TheDan64/inkwell/blob/master/examples/kaleidoscope/main.rs#L663)

**AST**
- Added ConditionalExpression and new_conditional. Should the fields on this be SubExpressions or something else?

**Mir**
- ast::Blocks with Expressions are converted into CompileResult<mir::Block>s with Statements
- Added Conditional Statement to mir/block/statement.rs
- Added lower_conditional_expression and matcher for it to pass/lower_ast.rs. What is the idea behind lowering the ast? Haven't come across it before.

**Codegen**
- Added matcher for Statement::Conditional to codegen/block/mod.rs
- Created codegen/block/gen_conditional.rs (from https://github.com/TheDan64/inkwell/blob/master/examples/kaleidoscope/main.rs#L999). This is the part I'm probs most unsure about, in the inkwell example everything is converted to floats using compile_expr. I'm not sure how to do the conditional comparison here or how best to return a PointerValue?

items.title: Compiled block optimizations

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

items.body:
At the moment, performance for audio generation in Axiom can be quite poor. Here are a few potential optimization-related tasks I've identified:

 - [ ] Add per-node profiling
 - [x] Pass num values by value to avoid allocas in node functions
 - [x] Use SSE and disable denormals with it
 - [x] Use fastcc for functions internally (not sure if this would make much of a difference, but it's a pretty simple change so probably worth it)
 - [ ] Look at why the reverb module uses so much time, and what can be done to improve it (I think this is related to the delay function being slow)
 - [x] Use tables for oscillators (and sin/cos in general?)
 - [ ] Optimize note function
 - [ ] Optimize biquad filters and delay function (why is delay so slow at the moment?)
 - [ ] Optimize the graph control (it's not too bad CPU wise, but we can expect to have a lot active at any moment in time and it should be possible to optimize a lot from the current implementation)

items.title: VST builds on macOS crash DAWs which scan them
items.body:
When Ableton Live 10 or JUCE Plugin Host scan the directory containing the VST builds of Axiom they crash on my machine, I haven't tried any other hosts yet. When Ableton crashes it gives a message that Axiom VST 2 Effect.vst could not be loaded, here is a stack trace of that when it is run in a debugger:

```
__pthread_kill 0x00007fff7b9afb66
pthread_kill 0x00007fff7bb7a080
abort 0x00007fff7b90b1ae
QMessageLogger::fatal(char const*, ...) const 0x0000000143149bdd
QGuiApplicationPrivate::createPlatformIntegration() 0x0000000142c2f794
QGuiApplicationPrivate::createEventDispatcher() 0x0000000142c2f7bb
QCoreApplicationPrivate::init() 0x0000000143314658
QGuiApplicationPrivate::init() 0x0000000142c2aad9
QApplicationPrivate::init() 0x000000012e55c41a
AxiomApplication::AxiomApplication() AxiomApplication.cpp:25
AxiomApplication::AxiomApplication() AxiomApplication.cpp:25
AxiomCommon::LazyInitializer<AxiomApplication>::get() optional:319
AxiomCommon::LazyInitializer<AxiomApplication>::get() optional:818
AxiomCommon::LazyInitializer<AxiomApplication>::get() LazyInitializer.h:27
AxiomVstPlugin::AxiomVstPlugin(long long (*)(AEffect*, int, int, long long, void*, float)) AxiomVstPlugin.cpp:16
AxiomVstPlugin::AxiomVstPlugin(long long (*)(AEffect*, int, int, long long, void*, float)) AxiomVstPlugin.cpp:16
::VSTPluginMain(audioMasterCallback) AxiomVstPlugin.cpp:10
```
I don't seem to be able to get the QT source code to load in my debugger, so haven't gone much further. Neither plugin is visible to load in Ableton after this.

When JUCE Plugin Host scans the Axiom plugins it gives the following log:
```
Attempting to load VST: /Users/user/Bounce/groove-axiom/cmake-build-debug/editor/backend/vst2/Axiom VST2 Effect.vst
Creating VST instance: Axiom VST2 Effect
Using data path /Users/user/Library/Application Support/Axiom
Loading module library took 0.192188s
2018-11-07 23:36:10.615356+0000 AudioPluginHost[95826:8515891] QLayout: Attempting to add QLayout "" to AxiomGui::ModuleBrowserPanel "", which already has a layout
2018-11-07 23:36:10.615412+0000 AudioPluginHost[95826:8515891] QLayout: Attempting to add QLayout "" to AxiomGui::ModuleBrowserPanel "", which already has a layout
Patch took 0.003489216s
Codegen took 0.003489809s
Deploy took 0.004540505s
*** Unhandled VST Callback: 13
*** Unhandled VST Callback: 42
Initialising VST: Axiom VST2 Effect (1.0.0.0)
Attempting to load VST: /Users/user/Bounce/groove-axiom/cmake-build-debug/editor/backend/vst2/Axiom VST2 Instrument.vst
2018-11-07 23:36:12.294087+0000 AudioPluginHost[95826:8515891] Cannot find executable for CFBundle 0x7fe1f300b8f0 </Users/user/Bounce/groove-axiom/cmake-build-debug/editor/backend/vst2/Axiom VST2 Instrument.vst> (not loaded)
```
It then says that Axiom VST2 Instrument.vst did not load correctly.  The Editor plugin loads and runs in JUCE Plugin Host but the Instrument is not visible.

Please advise how I should get Axiom running in Ableton and if there is any more information that would be useful to you.

items.title: High pass Bi-quad Filter 0V Output

milestone.description: Main Features include the exporter, XY control, scissors tool, oscilloscope visual, dB meter visual, an in-built keyboard and squashed bugs.

items.body: If the High BQ Filter is connected up without touching the frequency or q knobs, the output of the filter is 0V. If the frequency is changed, even slightly, the output then acts as normal.

items.title: Edits to README.md
items.body:
Edited the "highly customizable and flexible..." bullet point of features section. Changed "...a node editor and custom scripting language, named Maxim" to "...a node editor and Maxim, a custom scripting language." The edit clarifies that it's only the custom scripting language that is called Maxim (if that is what you meant).

Edited presentation of instructions in building backend. The two separate instructions are in bullets and are each preceded by a bolded title . It is now clear to the reader that there are two options in building backends.

Fixes #143

items.title: Replace Qt docking system with ADS

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include new modules, syntax highlighting, graph controls, UI enhancements and squashed bugs.

items.body:
Introduces a slightly modified version of the Advanced Docking System from https://github.com/githubuser0xFFFF/Qt-Advanced-Docking-System, which is more easily stylable, doesn't have as many "lock-ups" as Qt's one, and works better for what we want.

The Advanced Docking System is LGPL licensed, so I've added a note in the root LICENSE file and put in a sub-license in the ADS folder. I think that should be enough to cover the terms required, although I might end up needing to move the ADS to a separate repo.

items.title: Stop using Steinberg VST2 library to fix CI

labels.name: backend
labels.description: Issues related to audio backends

items.body:
Steinberg are in the process of winding down VST2, and seem to have removed some necessary parts from their download, which are used for the CI build. Various other projects which include the SDK in their source have been hit with DMCA takedowns, so it looks like we'll need to move to something else to provide the VST2 library.

LMMS has the [VeSTige header](https://github.com/LMMS/lmms/blob/master/include/aeffectx.h) which looks like the best option. It is GPL licensed, however, which might cause a problem with our MIT license. Some research will be necessary to see if we're allowed to use a similar approach to now where the header isn't included in our source, but must be downloaded separately when building the VST backend.

items.title: Clean up Audio Backend interface

labels.name: backend
labels.description: Issues related to audio backends

items.body: The Audio Backend interface is a bit messy at the moment, since it works on a weird inheritance-based system. A nice way of cleaning this up would be to convert it to a C-API, which would also allow backends to be written in other languages (helpful in the goal of slowly moving parts of the project over to Rust).

items.title: Fix group node crashes, fixes #99
items.body: Fixes a bunch of crashes related to the runtime not being kept up-to-date properly, by using a dirty/clean system instead of the adhoc "append the items to compile to this list" system. ModelObjects set themselves as dirty internally, normally though events (e.g. see NodeSurface). This means all of the things that make an object dirty can be seen by looking at that object, instead of needing to look everywhere.

items.body: Advanced filters in Axiom would allow for more control over filter behaviour, provides ways to improve CPU performance by picking the filter for the job and provides a way for more interesting filter sound/effects. Potential options include a filter model selection (Chebyshev, Butterworth), filter type (lowpass, highpass) and highest order. May also allow custom filter designs based on transfer functions.

items.title: Group Node crashes

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include new modules, syntax highlighting, graph controls, UI enhancements and squashed bugs.

items.body:
I've noticed a few crashes in certain situations with Group Nodes, where the wrong things are compiled (or in the wrong order), leading to a panic in the compiler. I think the compile system needs a bit of a rethink.

It's worth noting that even though these trigger crashes in the compiler, they're due to the editor passing in malformed MIR. It might be useful at some point to have a MIR verifier pass to catch these kinds of things earlier and highlight the actual issues.

items.title: Common rewrite, fixes #88 and #90

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include new modules, syntax highlighting, graph controls, UI enhancements and squashed bugs.

items.body:
This PR contains a rewrite of the "common code" - the event and sequence system. It now makes much better use of templates and move semantics to avoid heap allocation where possible, and in general hopefully lead to less hard-to-track bugs. It also has some performance improvements, like using a hashmap for finding ModelObjects based on UUID (instead of linear search), and caching sequences at certain critical spots (like the list of nodes in a surface), meaning we don't need to iterate over the entire pool all the time.

In the process of this I have found and fixed a few unrelated bugs and crashes. There are still some more focused around group nodes and compilation, however instead of patching over the plugs I'm planning to do some proper fixing up.

items.title: Syntax Highlighter - Errors

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include new modules, syntax highlighting, graph controls, UI enhancements and squashed bugs.

items.body:
Currently, if there is an error in the code of a node, the node appears to shutdown and isn't responsive to any changes e.g. adding or deleting controls. If there is an error in the code, the line in question should show up in a bold red to make it obvious:
a) that the node isn't responsive because there's a bug, and
b) where the bug is causing an issue.

items.title: Exporter

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

labels.name: compiler
labels.description: Issues related to the editor's runtime/compiler

labels.name: exporter
labels.description: Issues related to the exporter and exporter-generated code

items.body:
The exporter allows converting the graph into a standalone executable. It outputs two pieces of information: code and metadata.

Code formats:
 - LLVM bitcode (allows LTO linking with Clang/Rust/etc)
 - Object file

Metadata formats:
 - Header file (for use in the host code)
 - Other formats like JSON for other tools? (e.g. tool that combines multiple instruments)

Exporting also enables several MIR optimization passes aiming to reduce code size as much as possible:

 - Surface/block deduplication
 - Group flattening (where it makes sense)
 - Dead node/control/socket removal
   - Controls/value groups/sockets that aren't read from can be removed (this takes care of "user" knobs)
   - Nodes that don't have an output that ends up at a surface output

items.title: Add global module library, fixes #42

items.title: Hold Module Causes Permanent Output

labels.name: editor
labels.description: Issues related to the graphical editor

milestone.description: Main Features include new modules, syntax highlighting, graph controls, UI enhancements and squashed bugs.

items.body: Connecting a Hold module to an output with a Multiply hooked up (multiply set to 0), and then playing some notes causes the output to produce a constant volume. The work around is to disconnect something to make the whole synth reload which then removes the constant output (until played again).
